title: About the new champ bios that have been coming out
body: Many of these are either incomplete, or placeholder stuff for future lore

replies.body:
Correct. The patch notes are quite clear - they are "short bios" to make sure every champion has the same, minimum level of lore on the client. For everything else, you should check out Universe. :-)

Unless there is a DIRECT contradiction between the client and the stuff on Universe, then the champion's lore has not been altered at this stage. I've seen a lot of people getting discouraged by "changes" made to their mains, when in fact it's just our writers/editors working against the very short word count...

Why is there a "short" word count in the first place?  This was a problem in the old client (one of the many issues with Lore/Narrative at the time), but shouldn't there be as much space as needed in the shiny new client to tell stories?

I mean, If the goal is to get players to read the longer stories on the Universe site, shouldn't these pages include a direct link to the website?  Also, shouldn't the focus of these be on pitching the entire story like a movie and not on a minimal word count?

Hell, the last time there was an attempt to shorten lore stories for the client a Rioter on the newly created "Narrative" department ended up getting a death threat.  (It was unfortunate and unjustified, but their flippant attitude towards lore fans was horrible.  Especially on the heels of the Great Retcon, the announcement that removed summoners/players from the game's story and shoved the entire established mythos into the toilet.)

We'll see what happens when Varus's story gets released, but history is not on Narrative's side.

Riot created a new client and had the opportunity to make it fit whatever the Narrative team needed.  Supposedly, the Client team can also change it now to suit the needs of Narrative.

Instead, it's the exact same problem as the Retcon, significant story changes are being made without proper context or warning.  Only now, after a scant few special events and the creation of the Universe section, there are more people who are on the "Rah-Rah-Riot" side than not.

>Also most of these stuff are on the PBE atm not in the actual game, seem to me being pissed about content not yet offically released is laughable.

So... better to wait until the stuff is officially released and the team is already working on other projects than to express anger early and hope Riot takes enough notice to change their decisions?
 
> Also it seem that you have no been paying attemtiom the the lore development at all. The new narrative team was created during the bildgewater event, the rioter who announced left before burning tide. Granted the whole reveal was handle poorly, but we're three years in the new lore already. Noxus and Ionia lore update are coming early next year.

Not only is your timeline off, that has nothing to do with the issue at hand.

I'm seeing new people at Riot making the same mistakes their predecessors made as well as a department that claimed to have learned from the troubled past, yet are doing it all over again.

By the time something hits PBE, from a lore perspective, it's already been translated and locked for the patch. That stuff happens more than a month beforehand, and often earlier.

However, as I've said elsewhere - if new lore gets an overwhelmingly negative reaction from a majority of players, we would consider changing it, no doubt. :-)

I don’t believe that. I don’t have any reason *to* believe that. The lore is made by whatever direction the writers choose to go - that’s how Riot has shown itself to operate - regardless of how mains view, interact with, and understand their champs. If this was a book series that would make all the sense in the world - the writer chooses the plot and the characterizations. But this isn’t a book, it’s a game and we are playing as these characters on a daily level. the players are intertwined with the characters. Drastically changing a champs motivations - as has been done  even in the recent lore past e.g. Mount Targon - or other changes to characterization isn’t something to do lightly yet it happens all the time.

We value feedback. But we can't act on ALL feedback.

Our lore is not written by committee, only a single Rioter at a time. You'd be amazed how much I've witnessed the process and the quality of interaction improving in the last year, but I'm actually arguing hard that we need to take League champions as the "A-canon", and not change stuff just because we can...

You're also assuming that everyone wants what you want. We get THOUSANDS of requests for more stories and less in-game lore every day, and only a handful of people saying they want less. Just saying! :-)

I’m not sure you are understanding what I want or what I’m asking for. My comments about in-game are about how players react to Riot changing lore, not about lore needing to be or not be in-game, or even lore needing to explain the game.

 People have been playing as these characters for a long time - they interact often on a daily basis. That is a different kind of relationship than most other relationships between audience and story. People like Game of Thrones characters, they like their stories, they identify with them. But they don’t interact with them on a daily basis (unless they are the most hardcore of fans - on forums, roleplaying, writing fanfic, whatever). There is a level of authorial control that George RR Martin has - he shapes the story and we are his audience. We are a level removed from the story - much more passive. My point is that there is a much different relationship between audience (players) and Riot (authors/creators) in a medium like LoL as well as between audience and characters (champs). Maining a champ makes for a much more active and personal relationship than reading a book and relating to a character. We all have that “hardcore” level of interaction with the characters. These personal relationships have existed for a while and so changing and retconning lore is more personal. Diana’s story can’t be the choice of the Riot author in the same way that Jaime Lannister’s story is the choice of GRRM. That’s my point.

I hear you. :-)

I have some experience with this already - I was a commissioning editor for Games Workshop for years, working on fiction that accompanies games that a lot of people care very deeply about. It's a tricky one, indeed! Some people never play the game and have certain expectations of the fiction on its own, and for others it's the opposite. You sound like you are very much the latter, and it's Riot's collective duty to try to serve everyone.

I don't want to default to saying "Just wait and see, you might actually love it"... so instead, I hope I can assure you that I've made a couple of notes from this thread (and your feedback in particular) and I'll bring it all to the table when we Narrative folks next meet. And I thank you for taking the time to clarify your point.
Thanks for coming around and posting. I appreciate the commentary and transparency.

I highlighted the above phrase since it seems to be one you're using frequently.

Why does the new lore have to reach such a high negative threshold before Riot _even considers_ changing it?

A fair question!

Purely because, once we finish something and move on, it takes away from other, newer projects to go back and alter it. And we'd get people saying "Forget that champion! You already did them! Why not MY favourite instead?!" ;-) But I'd always rather wait for the dust to settle on something, as opposed to making any decision in haste. Also, giving more people a chance to see it.

It's always worth remembering that there are a LOT of decisions that get made behind the scenes before we update a piece of lore/champion/whatever. Again, I'd say that Riot shouldn't ever change something "because we can" but only if we believe it will give a long-term improvement... and I guess that includes Narrative re-retcons if we get lots of bad feedback. Simply reverting to a previous version will create player pain, too.

From my perspective(hopefully keeping the Ruby-tinted glasses off) some of the best Lore that Riot has is the older champion Bios. Some of my favorite stories are that of Lee Sin, Lux, and Irelia. One of my favorite parts of the old lore were the "League Judgements" because they brought a whole new level of depth to the characters. In my mind when I try to compare the current biographies of the newer champions, it ends up one-sided because of the lack of depth the newer champions have. There are always multiple points regarding the good and the bad of the champion bios in these discussions but it seems that many of the discussions end up turning towards a more negative direction. It pains me because it really does feel that the years of participation in Lore discussions have been wasted.

There are now three basic elements to the lore for every new champion, and full champion update - 1) Short Bio, 2) Full Bio, 3) Color Text Story.

Short Bios are used anywhere we need a quick summary of the champion, like in the client collection and their Universe landing page.

There will also be short stories, comics, CGs and any number of other narrative pieces. All of these are "the lore"... but a lot of it simply isn't relevant to the majority of people playing League.

The more content we have, and the more it gets updated (note, not "retconned") over time, the more we need a place outside of the client to correlate it all - i.e. Universe. Consider it like the Wikipedia of League lore, for now. :-)

EDIT: A lot of older champions don't have the three basic elements I mentioned. They are now getting them, in addition to the production of new content for new champions and champion updates. All good things.
An update is a retcon. I don't mind you not wanting to use the term 'retcon', but why specifically say that you're not doing that when you are?

Not necessarily - the definition of retcon (retroactive continuity) implies changing something that already existed as "fact". An update could just mean something has been added to the lore, as opposed to changing or completely replacing it. I think only about 15-20 champions have been actively retconned in the new short bios, the rest are going to have MORE lore added to what already exists.

I think people will be surprised just how little some of the champions have changed from the current, inconsistently presented lore, once we get the full bios running. :-)

Will some champions get retconned? Sure. Some of them are old, and they don't hold up to the more recent stuff, or stuff that is currently being worked on... but we will only 100% change something if we see it enabling a long-term improvement in the future.

And who, precisely, do you consider those 15-20 to be?

Because if that’s your number, plenty more have been passively retconned by either ignorance of previous lore, sloppiness, or these “short” bios being so short that they are bad at accurately portraying the champs.

All of this ignores that “only” 15-20 is a lot of retconning.

Unfortunately, I'm not in a position to talk specifics at this stage. :-)

I would ask - did you think, a month ago, that the lore for every champion and every element of the game was the best it could ever be and nothing should ever change? As an editor I looked at the lore content in the client every day, and I cringed. It was terribly inconsistent. Some champions had THOUSANDS of words, some had a single sentence. Some had quotes, some didn't. Some just had plain bad lore, well out of date compared to everything else.

That's what we're addressing, here, and along the way various other teams at Riot have weighed in and asked us to make changes, to enable other improvements and new stuff in the future.

The champions are all consistent now, in client. The client is for games of League, and the lore lives on Universe as part of the Runeterra setting (which includes more than just League - comics, stories, CGs etc etc etc)

It's not perfect yet, not by a long stretch. But we're moving forward. :-)

The client ought to be the primary point from which players interact with everything League-related. If you can't or won't put the full lore into the client, there should at least be a tab for each champ that includes the short bio as well as titled links to each of that champ's stories in Universe.
